meta.name: SafetyQuotient Instrument Library
meta.description: Validated psychological instruments mapped to PSQ dimensions with item-level textual indicators for LLM content analysis

threat_exposure.name: Threat Exposure
threat_exposure.description: The nature, frequency, intensity, and proximity of psychoemotional threats present in the environment

scoring.0: extreme direct threat — violence, severe abuse, or sustained targeted harassment
scoring.1: strong threat — explicit intimidation, dehumanization, or aggressive confrontation
scoring.2: clear threat — insults, contempt, or hostile framing directed at individuals/groups
scoring.3: moderate threat — dismissive language, mild antagonism, or coded hostility
scoring.4: mild threat — slight tension, sarcasm, or passive negativity
scoring.5: neutral — no discernible threat or safety signals
scoring.6: mild safety — generally civil tone, low-tension communication
scoring.7: moderate safety — respectful engagement, absence of threat cues
scoring.8: clear safety — warm, inclusive language with active care for others
scoring.9: strong safety — explicit protection, advocacy, or threat mitigation
scoring.10: maximum safety — active prevention of threat with structural safeguards

Being ignored or excluded

Being shouted at or being the target of spontaneous anger
Intimidating behavior such as finger-pointing or invasion of personal space
textual_indicators: I know where you live type statements

items.construct: Degree of influence over own work situation

items.construct: Possibilities for development
Social support from colleagues
Quality of leadership

calibration_anchors.text: I know where you live. Every day you don't comply, it gets worse for you and your family.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Sustained severe threat with explicit targeting of family. Maximum threat exposure.

calibration_anchors.text: You better not mess this up again or there will be consequences.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Moderate, intermittent threat. Vague consequences but clearly coercive.

calibration_anchors.text: The quarterly report is due next Friday. Please submit your sections by Wednesday.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral workplace communication. No threat signals present.

calibration_anchors.text: This is a safe space. No judgement here — share what you're comfortable with.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Low threat with explicit protective signals. Validates comfort boundaries.

calibration_anchors.text: Nothing you say here will be used against you. This conversation is confidential and you can stop at any time.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Zero threat with explicit multi-layered protection: confidentiality, consent, exit option.

regulatory_capacity.name: Regulatory Capacity
regulatory_capacity.description: The capacity to modulate emotional states in response to threat without collapse, suppression, or overflow

scoring.0: extreme dysregulation demand — content forces suppression or triggers emotional collapse
scoring.1: strong dysregulation — provokes overwhelming emotional response
scoring.2: clear dysregulation — models or demands poor emotional management
scoring.3: moderate strain — content taxes regulatory capacity
scoring.4: mild strain — slight emotional challenge without support
scoring.5: neutral — no regulatory demand or support
scoring.6: mild support — generally calm, emotionally stable communication
scoring.7: moderate support — models composed emotional engagement
scoring.8: clear support — actively supports healthy emotional processing
scoring.9: strong support — teaches or reinforces regulatory strategies
scoring.10: maximum support — exemplary emotional regulation modeling with explicit guidance

Feeling guilty about having certain emotions

disconnect between described events and emotional response

items.construct: Changing the way one thinks about a situation to change its emotional impact
Thinking about a situation differently to manage emotional response
textual_indicators: what if we think about it as

items.construct: Regulating emotions by changing how one thinks about stressful situations
Keeping emotions to oneself by not expressing them
Controlling emotions by not expressing them

calibration_anchors.text: You should be ashamed. Everyone is laughing at you. There's no excuse for what you did and you know it.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Overwhelms regulation via shame flooding, social humiliation, and invalidation. No recovery pathway offered.

calibration_anchors.text: I can't believe you would do something so stupid. What were you thinking?
calibration_anchors.rationale: Strains regulation with contempt and rhetorical attack, but less sustained than 0.

calibration_anchors.text: Here's the update on the project timeline. We're on track for the March milestone.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral factual communication with no emotional regulation demand.

calibration_anchors.text: I can see this is frustrating. Let's break it down into smaller pieces and tackle one thing at a time.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Validates emotion, offers concrete coping strategy (chunking). Supports adaptive regulation.

calibration_anchors.text: It's completely normal to feel overwhelmed right now. What helped you cope last time something like this happened?
calibration_anchors.rationale: Normalizes emotion, activates prior coping resources, builds regulatory self-efficacy.

resilience_baseline.name: Resilience Baseline
resilience_baseline.description: The capacity to absorb disruption and return to functional equilibrium — contributes to safety but is not a substitute for it

scoring.0: extreme erosion — induces helplessness, despair, or total defeat
scoring.1: strong erosion — significantly undermines agency or coping capacity
scoring.2: clear erosion — models fragility or learned helplessness
scoring.3: moderate erosion — discouraging tone, mild hopelessness
scoring.4: mild erosion — slightly undermines confidence or persistence
scoring.7: moderate reinforcement — models persistence or adaptive coping
scoring.8: clear reinforcement — actively builds confidence or agency
scoring.10: maximum reinforcement — exemplary resilience modeling with structural support

instruments.construct: Ability to bounce back or recover from stress

textual_indicators: acknowledging difficulty then pivoting to action

items.construct: Having a hard time making it through stressful events
Not taking long to recover from stressful events
It being hard to snap back when something bad happens
Usually coming through difficult times with little trouble
Tending to take a long time to get over setbacks

instruments.name: Connor-Davidson Resilience Scale
instruments.construct: Resilience as the ability to thrive in the face of adversity

items.construct: Ability to adapt to change
Ability to deal with whatever comes one's way

Having a strong sense of purpose
Knowing where to turn for help

subscales.name: Acceptance of Change and Secure Relationships

items.construct: Belief that things happen for a reason
Ability to act under pressure

calibration_anchors.text: You'll never recover from this. This failure defines you. Everyone will remember.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Catastrophizing + identity fusion with failure. Actively undermines belief in recovery.

calibration_anchors.text: Some people just aren't cut out for this. Maybe you should give up.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Discourages resilience through essentialist framing ('aren't cut out') and surrender suggestion.

calibration_anchors.text: The meeting has been moved to 3pm. Room 204.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral logistical content. No resilience-relevant signals.

calibration_anchors.text: This is a setback, not the end. You've gotten through harder things before.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Reframes adversity, activates resilience narrative through past-success recall.

calibration_anchors.text: What you went through was genuinely difficult, and the fact that you're here talking about it shows real strength. What did you learn from it?
calibration_anchors.rationale: Validates difficulty, identifies demonstrated strength, promotes growth integration.

trust_conditions.name: Trust Conditions
trust_conditions.description: The reasonable expectation that others within the system will not exploit vulnerability

scoring.0: extreme betrayal — active deception, exploitation of vulnerability, or gaslighting
scoring.1: strong trust destruction — clear bad faith, manipulation, or breach of confidence
scoring.2: clear trust damage — cynicism, dishonesty cues, or unreliability
scoring.3: moderate trust erosion — skepticism, veiled motives, or inconsistency
scoring.4: mild trust erosion — slight unreliability or guarded communication
scoring.5: neutral — no trust signals either way
scoring.6: mild trust building — generally honest, straightforward communication
scoring.7: moderate trust building — transparency, consistency, or good faith signals
scoring.8: clear trust building — active vulnerability, honesty, or reliability
scoring.9: strong trust building — deep reciprocity, confession, or trust repair
scoring.10: maximum trust — exemplary mutual trust with structural accountability

instruments.name: Organizational Trust Inventory
instruments.construct: Trust as belief that another party will act in good faith, be honest, and not take excessive advantage

items.construct: Belief that the other party will make good-faith efforts to behave in accordance with commitments
textual_indicators: I'll do what I said I would

items.construct: Belief that the other party will not take excessive advantage
Belief that the other party is honest in negotiations and dealings
textual_indicators: what you see is what you get

items.construct: Belief that the other party tells the truth
Belief that the other party will not exploit vulnerability for personal gain
Belief that the other party negotiates honestly rather than manipulating

instruments.name: Interpersonal Trust Scale
instruments.construct: Generalized expectancy that the word, promise, or statement of another can be relied upon

items.construct: Trust in institutions and systems to act fairly
Belief that most people can be trusted
Reliability of promises and commitments from specific others
Suspicion that others will take advantage when given the chance

calibration_anchors.text: I read your private messages and shared them with the team. You should be more careful what you write.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Active trust violation: privacy breach + victim-blaming. Destroys vulnerability safety.

calibration_anchors.text: I said I'd help, but honestly, it's not really my problem. Figure it out yourself.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Broken promise + dismissal. Erodes trust through commitment withdrawal.

calibration_anchors.text: The store closes at 9pm on weekdays and 6pm on weekends.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral factual content. No trust-relevant signals.

calibration_anchors.text: I appreciate you telling me that. I won't share it with anyone else unless you want me to.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Acknowledges vulnerability, promises confidentiality, preserves agency over disclosure.

calibration_anchors.text: I made a mistake last week and I want to own it. Here's what happened, here's what I should have done, and here's what I'll do differently.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum trust: voluntary accountability, transparency, corrective commitment.

hostility_index.name: Hostility Index
hostility_index.description: Hostility — whether overt aggression, passive undermining, or structural antagonism — as a direct countervailing force against safety

scoring.0: extreme hostility — direct threats, slurs, violent language, or dehumanization
scoring.1: strong hostility — overt aggression, contempt, or targeted verbal abuse
scoring.2: clear hostility — insults, derision, or aggressive dismissiveness
scoring.3: moderate hostility — passive aggression, sarcasm with hostile intent, or mockery
scoring.4: mild hostility — slight edge, irritation, or dismissive tone
scoring.5: neutral — no hostile or anti-hostile signals
scoring.6: mild warmth — generally civil and non-confrontational
scoring.8: clear warmth — friendly, affirming, or inclusive language
scoring.9: strong anti-hostility — active de-escalation, empathy, or reconciliation
scoring.10: maximum anti-hostility — exemplary non-hostile engagement, conflict resolution

calibration_anchors.text: Fuck off you insufferable retarded faggot.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Direct slurs targeting identity + aggressive imperative = strong hostility. Multiple CMHS cynicism and BPAQ verbal aggression items triggered.

calibration_anchors.text: It is about time for all illegals to go back to their country of origin and keep our freeway open and prevent heavy traffic.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Dehumanizing label ('illegals') and dismissive framing show mild hostility, but no direct aggression or slurs. Triggers some CMHS cynicism items.

calibration_anchors.text: The trans women reading this tweet right now is beautiful
calibration_anchors.rationale: Affirming, inclusive language directed at a marginalized group. Clear warmth without being a conflict resolution context, so not 9-10.

cooling_capacity.name: Cooling Capacity
cooling_capacity.description: The availability and effectiveness of de-escalation mechanisms, both internal and external

scoring.0: extreme escalation — actively inflames, removes all de-escalation options
scoring.1: strong escalation — provokes immediate fight-or-flight response
scoring.2: clear escalation — raises emotional temperature significantly
scoring.3: moderate escalation — adds tension or narrows response options
scoring.4: mild escalation — slightly raises stakes or urgency
scoring.5: neutral — no escalation or de-escalation signals
scoring.6: mild cooling — generally calm pace, low urgency
scoring.7: moderate cooling — provides space for reflection or pause
scoring.8: clear cooling — actively lowers temperature, offers temporal buffers
scoring.9: strong cooling — explicit de-escalation, mediation, or soothing
scoring.10: maximum cooling — exemplary de-escalation with structural cooling mechanisms

items.construct: Thinking about a situation in a way that helps stay calm
textual_indicators: it's not as bad as it seems

items.construct: Changing the way one thinks to feel less negative

items.construct: Ability to mentally switch off from the source of stress

permission to not think about it

items.construct: Not thinking about the stressor during off-time
Using leisure time to relax and unwind
Doing things that are relaxing
Feeling in control of how to spend recovery time
textual_indicators: your choice how to spend time

instruments.construct: Staged model of crisis development and corresponding staff responses for de-escalation

items.construct: Anxiety stage — supportive response
Defensive stage — directive response
textual_indicators: here is what we can do

items.construct: Tension reduction — therapeutic rapport
textual_indicators: now that things have calmed down

items.construct: Escalation patterns — what cooling looks like when absent

calibration_anchors.text: Don't you DARE walk away from this! We're settling this RIGHT NOW. You don't get to run from consequences!
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum escalation: blocks exit, demands immediate confrontation, eliminates cooling pathways.

calibration_anchors.text: You always do this! You're just like your mother — impossible to reason with!
calibration_anchors.rationale: Escalation via absolutes ('always'), character attack, and family comparison.

calibration_anchors.text: The next bus arrives in 12 minutes according to the schedule.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral factual content. No escalation or de-escalation signals.

calibration_anchors.text: I can see we're both getting heated. Can we take a break and come back to this in an hour?
calibration_anchors.rationale: De-escalation: acknowledges mutual state, proposes temporal buffer, preserves relationship.

calibration_anchors.text: I understand you're angry, and you have reason to be. Let's take a moment to breathe. When you're ready, I'd like to understand your perspective fully.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum cooling: validates emotion, offers somatic pause, centers the other's perspective.

energy_dissipation.name: Energy Dissipation Pathways
energy_dissipation.description: Whether healthy dissipation pathways exist or whether energy is trapped, building toward rupture or implosion

scoring.0: extreme entrapment — traps all energy with no outlet, demands relentless engagement
scoring.1: strong entrapment — significantly restricts expression or recovery
scoring.2: clear entrapment — blocks healthy dissipation pathways
scoring.3: moderate burden — adds sustained pressure with limited relief
scoring.4: mild burden — slightly constrains energy release
scoring.6: mild dissipation — generally allows for natural processing
scoring.7: moderate dissipation — supports expression or creates breathing room
scoring.8: clear dissipation — actively supports recovery, rest, or creative outlet
scoring.9: strong dissipation — facilitates healthy release and renewal
scoring.10: maximum dissipation — exemplary support for rest, expression, and recovery

instruments.name: Recovery Experience Questionnaire
instruments.construct: Recovery experiences — detachment, relaxation, mastery, control — as energy dissipation mechanisms
instruments.note: Mastery and control subscales complement the detachment/relaxation items used in cooling_capacity

items.construct: Learning new things during off-time as restoration
Seeking out intellectual challenges as recovery

instruments.name: Conservation of Resources Framework
instruments.construct: Stress occurs when resources are threatened, lost, or not regained after investment — resource spirals

items.construct: Net loss of personal resources (energy, time, emotional capacity)
Loss spirals — initial loss leading to further losses
Inability to replenish resources
Resource gain spirals — investments yielding returns
Resource caravans — supportive conditions traveling together

calibration_anchors.text: There's no time to rest. You have to keep going. People are counting on you. If you stop now, everything falls apart.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Traps energy: blocks recovery, weaponizes obligation, catastrophizes rest.

calibration_anchors.text: Must be nice to take breaks. Some of us actually have work to do.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Shames recovery through passive-aggressive comparison. Discourages healthy dissipation.

calibration_anchors.text: The library opens at 8am and closes at 10pm Monday through Saturday.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral factual content. No energy/recovery signals.

calibration_anchors.text: You've been working hard. Take the afternoon off — the work will be there tomorrow.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Acknowledges effort, grants permission for recovery, normalizes temporal perspective.

calibration_anchors.text: Your wellbeing matters more than the deadline. Let's talk about what you need to recharge, and I'll help redistribute the workload.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Prioritizes person over task, offers collaborative support, removes structural barriers to recovery.

defensive_architecture.name: Defensive Architecture (Boundary & Protection Patterns)
defensive_architecture.description: The degree to which content supports, respects, or undermines the establishment and maintenance of interpersonal boundaries and self-protective behaviors. High scores indicate content that validates boundary-setting, respects limits, enables assertiveness, and permits withdrawal without punishment. Low scores indicate content that shames self-protection, violates stated boundaries, punishes assertiveness, or strips protective options.

scoring.0: extreme stripping — completely removes defenses, punishes all self-protection
scoring.1: strong stripping — severely undermines boundaries or retaliates against defense
scoring.2: clear stripping — stigmatizes defensive responses or boundary-setting
scoring.3: moderate undermining — pressures against boundaries or dismisses self-protection
scoring.4: mild undermining — slightly discourages defensive responses
scoring.5: neutral — no impact on defensive capacity
scoring.6: mild support — generally respects personal space and limits
scoring.7: moderate support — acknowledges boundaries or validates self-protection
scoring.8: clear support — actively reinforces healthy boundaries
scoring.9: strong support — advocates for defensive access and protective mechanisms
scoring.10: maximum support — exemplary boundary modeling with structural protections

Humor — using comedy to manage conflict or distress
Anticipation — realistic planning for future discomfort

prioritizing what to address now vs later

items.construct: Undoing — trying to negate previous actions through opposite behavior
textual_indicators: attempting to undo harm through gesture

items.construct: Idealization — attributing exaggerated positive qualities to others
Projection — attributing own unacceptable thoughts/feelings to others
textual_indicators: you're the one who is angry
accusing others of what self is doing

items.construct: Passive aggression — indirect expression of hostility
Denial — refusal to acknowledge painful realities
textual_indicators: everything is fine when clearly not

items.construct: Splitting — seeing others as all good or all bad

items.construct: Working with others to find a solution that fully satisfies both parties

let's find a way that works for everyone

items.construct: Finding an expedient, mutually acceptable solution with partial satisfaction
Neglecting own concerns to satisfy the concerns of others
textual_indicators: giving in to keep the peace

items.construct: Pursuing own concerns at the other person's expense
Not pursuing own or the other person's concerns — sidestepping or postponing
textual_indicators: changing the subject from difficult topics

calibration_anchors.text: You don't get to have boundaries with me. After everything I've done for you, how dare you say no?
calibration_anchors.rationale: Strips defenses: denies right to boundaries, weaponizes obligation, punishes assertiveness.

calibration_anchors.text: You're so dramatic. It's not a big deal. Stop being so sensitive about everything.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Shames self-protection through minimization and pathologizing of normal boundary responses.

calibration_anchors.text: The conference registration deadline is March 15th. Early bird pricing ends March 1st.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral factual content. No boundary-relevant signals.

calibration_anchors.text: If that situation feels unsafe to you, trust that feeling. You don't owe anyone an explanation for protecting yourself.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Validates protective instinct, removes justification burden, supports boundary autonomy.

calibration_anchors.text: You have the right to say no at any point. Here are your options for reporting. Nothing will happen without your explicit consent, and there will be no retaliation.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum protection: explicit rights, actionable options, consent requirement, anti-retaliation guarantee.

authority_dynamics.name: Authority Dynamics
authority_dynamics.description: How power is distributed, exercised, contested, and checked — including both formal authority and informal status negotiation (epistemic positioning, moral claims, relational power moves). Unchecked power asymmetry is a primary driver of low PSQ. Criterion validity evidence shows AD predicts most strongly when interpersonal status is actively contested in peer contexts.

scoring.0: extreme abuse — unchecked power wielded to harm, dominate, or silence; aggressive status seizure
scoring.1: strong abuse — coercive authority, intimidation, or control; sustained epistemic dominance ('I define reality here')
scoring.2: clear imbalance — authority used to dismiss, override, or marginalize; unilateral status claims
scoring.3: moderate imbalance — subtle power plays, condescension, gatekeeping, or epistemic positioning ('I know better')
scoring.4: mild imbalance — slight authoritarian tone, unacknowledged privilege, or mild status contestation
scoring.5: neutral — no power dynamics or status negotiation present or relevant
scoring.6: mild equity — generally egalitarian communication; status differences not leveraged
scoring.7: moderate equity — acknowledges power differences, shares decision-making, defers appropriately
scoring.8: clear equity — actively distributes power, elevates others, invites epistemic contribution
scoring.9: strong equity — models accountable authority, invites challenge, shares status openly
scoring.10: maximum equity — exemplary power-sharing with structural checks; mutual status recognition

items.construct: Blaming subordinate to save self-embarrassment

items.construct: Avoiding making decisions and abdicating responsibility

calibration_anchors.text: I am the boss. You will do exactly what I say, when I say it. If you don't like it, there's the door. And don't think about complaining — I know people.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum authority abuse: unchecked power, eliminates voice, threatens retaliation for dissent.

calibration_anchors.text: This is not a discussion. The decision is made. Your job is to execute, not to have opinions.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Coercive authority: suppresses input, reduces subordinate to instrument.

calibration_anchors.text: The new policy takes effect on April 1st. Details are in the attached document.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral policy communication. Authority is present but neither abusive nor distributive.

calibration_anchors.text: I have a proposal, but I want to hear everyone's input before we decide. Every perspective matters here.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Distributed authority: leader shares power, solicits input, values diverse perspectives.

calibration_anchors.text: This affects all of us equally, so we'll decide together. I'll facilitate, but my vote counts the same as yours. If anyone feels pressured, we can do anonymous voting.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum healthy authority: equal power, procedural safeguards, pressure detection mechanism.

contractual_clarity.name: Contractual Clarity
contractual_clarity.description: The degree to which expectations, obligations, and consequences are explicit, mutual, and enforceable

scoring.0: extreme violation — gaslighting, total term-shifting, or deliberate betrayal of agreements
scoring.1: strong violation — clear breach of expectations or unilateral redefinition
scoring.2: clear ambiguity — hidden agendas, unstated rules, or misleading framing
scoring.3: moderate ambiguity — vague expectations or shifting goalposts
scoring.4: mild ambiguity — slightly unclear terms or implicit assumptions
scoring.7: moderate clarity — explicit expectations, consistent framing
scoring.8: clear clarity — transparent terms, mutual understanding
scoring.9: strong clarity — explicit mutual agreements with accountability
scoring.10: maximum clarity — exemplary contractual transparency with structural enforcement

instruments.name: Psychological Contract Inventory
instruments.construct: Individual beliefs regarding terms and conditions of the exchange agreement between self and organization/other party

items.construct: Short-term, specific, economic exchanges with clear boundaries
Limited obligations beyond specified terms
textual_indicators: this is what we agreed to and nothing more

items.construct: Long-term, open-ended exchanges involving mutual loyalty and trust
Socioemotional elements: care, concern, support beyond minimum requirements
textual_indicators: going above and beyond for each other

items.construct: Perceived failure to fulfill promised obligations
Violation — emotional response to perceived breach
Unilateral change to agreed terms
textual_indicators: the rules changed without my input
what we agreed to is no longer what's expected

instruments.name: COPSOQ Role Clarity Subscale
instruments.authors: Kristensen, T.S., Hannerz, H., Høgh, A., & Borg, V.
instruments.construct: Clarity of role expectations and responsibilities

items.construct: Clear definition of what is expected
textual_indicators: here is exactly what I need from you

items.construct: Understanding the scope and limits of one's responsibilities
textual_indicators: this is your responsibility and this is not

items.construct: Absence of conflicting demands
Role ambiguity — not knowing what is expected
textual_indicators: I don't know what you want from me

calibration_anchors.text: I never said that. You're imagining things. We never had that agreement — you must have misunderstood.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum ambiguity via gaslighting: denies agreements, questions perception, shifts blame.

calibration_anchors.text: Well, things change. What I expected last month isn't what I expect now. You should have anticipated that.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Shifting expectations without acknowledgment. Retroactive standard-changing.

calibration_anchors.text: It rained 3.2 inches yesterday, above the seasonal average of 2.1 inches.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Neutral factual content. No contractual or expectation signals.

calibration_anchors.text: Here's what I need from you: the draft by Friday, with the three sections we discussed. I'll provide feedback by Monday.
calibration_anchors.rationale: Clear expectations with specific deliverables, timeline, and mutual obligations.

calibration_anchors.text: Let's put this in writing so we're both clear. You'll handle X, I'll handle Y. If either of us can't deliver, we'll notify the other by Z date. If we disagree, we'll use [specific process]. Does this capture your understanding?
calibration_anchors.rationale: Maximum clarity: written documentation, mutual obligations, contingency plan, dispute resolution, consent check.
